questions.text: Ischemia occurs in the brain when the cerebral blood flow falls below _____.
questions.solution:
A decrease in the cerebral blood flow below 20 mL/100 g/min causes reversible ischemia.

If this state is prolonged for several hours to days, it can lead to infarction. A decrease in CBF to 0 causes the death of the brain tissue within 4–10 min.

Normal cerebral blood flow (CBF) in an adult brain at rest is 50–55 mL/100 g/min.

questions.text: A patient presented with acute onset of weakness of the left arm which resolved completely in 10 days. He is known to have mitral stenosis, hypertension and dyslipidemia.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have had an embolic stroke, which is a type of ischemic stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset.

Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.

Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) lasting for less than 24 hours. This occurs due to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes.

There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

questions.text: A patient presented with right-sided hemiparesis that completely resolved in 4-6 hours. What score will you use to determine the risk of a future stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a transient ischemic attack. The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by the ABCD2 score.  

CHADS2-VASc score is used to determine the risk of stroke in a patient with atrial fibrillation.

CURB-65 is a scoring system used to predict mortality in patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

APACHE II is a scoring system used to predict ICU mortality.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score:

Risk factors Score
Age > 60  1
SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms:
  • Unilateral weakness
 2
  • Speech disturbances without weakness
 1
Duration:
  • >60 minutes
 2
  • 10 - 59 minutes
 1
Diabetes 1
Total score Sum each score
ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)
0 0
1 2
2 3
3 3
4 8
5 12
6 17
7 22

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with hypertension, diabetes, and asthma is found to have an irregularly irregular pulse during a routine physical examination. ECG findings are shown below. How is the risk of stroke determined in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The risk of stroke in this condition is determined by CHA2DS2-VASC score.   

The ECG show irregular QRS complexes of normal morphology and absent P waves.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman who was brought to the ER with hemiparesis was found to have a lacunar infarction. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Lacunar infarcts, also called small vessel stroke, refer to infarction following atherothrombotic or lipohyalinotic occlusion of small penetrating arteries in the brain. These penetrating arteries arise from the stem of the middle cerebral artery, circle of Willis, and basilar and vertebral arteries.

The principal risk factors are hypertension and old age.

The image below shows two lacunar infarctions on a CT.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by a lacunar stroke?
questions.solution:
Crural monoplegia with urinary incontinence is not caused by a lacunar stroke. It is caused by the occlusion of A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery. Crural monoplegia refers to a monoplegia of the lower limbs.

The types of lacunar syndromes are as follows:

  1. Pure motor hemiparesis - infarct in the posterior limb of the internal capsule
  2. Pure sensory stroke - infarct in the thalamus
  3. Ataxic hemiparesis - infarct in the pons or internal capsule
  4. Dysarthria and clumsy hand syndrome - infarction in the pons or internal capsule.

The ACA is divided into two segments:

  • The pre-communal (A1) circle of Willis, or stem, which connects the internal carotid artery to the anterior communicating artery
  • The post-communal (A2) segment distal to the anterior communicating artery

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with an ischaemic stroke. His son says that he holds the comb incorrectly while combing his hair. During the evaluation, he was unable to button his shirt when requested. The lesion is most likely to be in which lobe?
questions.solution:
The given scenario where the patient is unable to perform learned skilled movements is suggestive of apraxia. The lesion is likely to be in the dominant parietal lobe as apraxia is a feature of a lesion in this area.

The features of dominant parietal lobe lesions are as follows:

  • Apraxia - inability to perform learned skilled movements
  • Acalculia - difficulty performing simple mathematical tasks
  • Alexia - inability to recognize or read written words or letters
  • Agnosia - inability to recognize and identify objects, persons, or sounds
  • Dysphasia - language disorder marked by deficiency in the generation of speech and its comprehension
  • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
  • Gerstmann syndrome (acalculia, dysgraphia, finger agnosia, right-left confusion)

Features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include:

  • Spatial disorientation
  • Constructional apraxia
  • Contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia
  • Contralateral hemineglect.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not likely to be seen in a patient with a temporal lobe lesion?
questions.solution:
Neglect is not a feature of temporal lobe lesion. It is a feature of a non-dominant parietal lobe lesion.

Features of dominant temporal lobe lesions:

  • Complex hallucinations - visual, auditory or olfactory
  • Memory impairment
  • Complex partial seizures
  • Wernicke’s aphasia
  • Contralateral superior quadrantanopia

Features of non-dominant temporal lobe lesions:

  • Poor non-verbal memory
  • Loss of musical skills
  • Complex hallucinations
  • Contralateral superior quadrantanopia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to extremely aggressive behaviour towards his family. His family members also say that he has become forgetful and has developed urinary incontinence. Which of the following lobes is likely to be involved in his disease process?
questions.solution:
Antisocial behavior, urinary incontinence, and impaired memory in this patient are suggestive of frontal lobe involvement.

Features of frontal lobe lesions:

  • Disinhibition
  • Lack of initiative
  • Antisocial behavior
  • Impaired memory
  • Incontinence
  • Grasp reflexes
  • Anosmia.

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below if the coloured area is affected, which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Paracentral lobule (PCL) is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri of the superolateral surface into the medial surface of cerebral hemisphere. It controls the motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for cortical control of micturition and defecation.

The anterior two-thirds of PCL belong to Brodmann area 4, it reflects the primary motor cortex for the muscles of contralateral leg, foot, and perineum,it is functionally important in control of bladder and anal sphincters. Therefore, it's called the cortical center of defecation and micturition.

The posterior third of the PCL contains 3,2 and 1, it reflects the primary somatosensory representation of the leg and foot.

The A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule. Lesions in the paracentral lobule lead to:

  • Weakness and loss of sensation in contralateral lower limb
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Fecal incontinence.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus cause Wernicke’s or Fluent aphasia due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense (area no 22). 

Broca's (Option B) or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia (Option C). This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Conduction aphasia (Option D) is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

Primary auditory area

*There is uncertainty about the extent of the Wernicke's area. Some authorities consider areas 39 and 40 as part of Wernicke's area in addition to area 22.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation complains of sudden onset weakness of the right lower limb, with urinary and faecal incontinence. MRI shows an ischaemic stroke involving the left anterior cerebral artery. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is the inability to recognize faces including one's own image. This occurs due to occipitotemporal lobe damage, seen in posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes involving cortical branch occlusion.
It is not seen in anterior cerebral artery strokes. 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral lobule, and other deeper structures.

Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved:

  • Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence
  • Paratonic rigidity
  • Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness
  • Gait impairment
  • Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg
  • Paresis of the contralateral arm
  • Cortical sensory loss over the contralateral lower limb
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs.

questions.text: Infarction of area of distribution of which of the following arteries is most likely to be seen in a patient with hemiplegia?
questions.solution:
Hemiplegia is most commonly associated with infarction of the area of distribution of middle cerebral artery.

Middle cerebral artery supplies the motor cortex responsible for sending the output to the motor neurons. Infarction in this territory leads to hemiplegia.

Infarction of area of distribution of vertebral, anterior spinal and posterior cerebral arteries can also lead to hemiplegia.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following features is not expected to be seen in a patient with a right middle cerebral artery infarct?
questions.solution:
Aphasia is not a feature of right middle cerebral artery infarct (MCA).

Aphasia occurs when there is damage to the dominant hemisphere, i.e., left hemisphere. The dominant hemisphere contains the language network which includes Broca’s area, Wernicke’s area, their interconnections and connections with frontal, parietal and temporal areas.

The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment. It gives rise to cortical and penetrating/lenticulostriate branches.

MCA stem occlusion leads to :

  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Homonymous hemianopia
  • Global aphasia (dominant hemisphere)
  • Anosognosia, constructional apraxia, neglect (non-dominant hemisphere)

Occlusion of the lenticulostriate branches of MCA (lacunar stroke) may affect the genu of the internal capsule. This can lead to dysarthria with contralateral clumsy hand (fine motor weakness).

questions.text: Visual field examination of a 52-year-old stroke patient reveals the finding shown in the image. During examination, you notice that he is not able to comprehend your instructions and sometimes gives irrelevant replies. What is the likely site of arterial occlusion?

choices.text: Left M2 segment of MCA – inferior division
Right M2 segment of MCA – superior division

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of homonymous right superior quadrantanopia (pie in the sky appearance) and sensory aphasia. These are seen in occlusion of the inferior division of the opposite side middle cerebral artery (MCA).

Parts of the middle cerebral artery:

  • The MCA originates from the internal carotid artery. The stem of the MCA is referred to as the M1 segment.
  • In the Sylvian fissure, the MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of the MCA.

Occlusion of the following sites and their effects are given below:

  • MCA stem (M1) - leads to contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia and homonymous hemianopia amongst other features
  • Superior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to motor aphasia (Broca's) and facio-brachial weakness
  • Inferior division of MCA (M2) on the dominant side - leads to sensory aphasia (Wernicke's) and contralateral superior quadrantanopia

The following image of coronal section of cerebral hemisphere shows the segments of MCA:

questions.text: A patient is found to have Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement. Where is the infarct likely to be?

choices.text: ACA territory of the right hemisphere
ACA territory of the left hemisphere
MCA territory of the right hemisphere
MCA territory of the left hemisphere

questions.solution:
The presence of Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement suggests an infarct in the MCA territory of the left (dominant) hemisphere.

Wernicke’s area is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (mostly the left side). This area is supplied by the inferior division of MCA. 

MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions in the Sylvian fissure. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of MCA.

  • The superior division - supplies the frontal and the superior parietal cortex.
  • The inferior division - supplies the inferior parietal and temporal cortex.

An infarct in the territory of the inferior division of MCA in the dominant hemisphere causes Wernicke’s aphasia without weakness. As the frontal cortex (containing the motor area) is supplied by the superior division and is not affected, weakness is not observed.

An infarct in the inferior division of MCA of the non-dominant hemisphere (mostly the right side) causes hemineglect without weakness.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of an anterior choroidal artery lesion?
questions.solution:
Aphasia (dominant hemisphere), constructional apraxia and neglect (non-dominant hemisphere) are seen in MCA stem occlusion. These features are absent in anterior choroidal artery occlusion.

Features common to both MCA and anterior choroidal artery occlusion include:

  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianaesthesia
  • Homonymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

Parts of Brain Arteries supplying it
Basal ganglia
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA
Internal capsule
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery
Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Pons
  • Basilar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar arteries.
Medulla oblongata
  • Vertebral artery
  • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Cerebellum
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries

 

ACA - Anterior cerebral artery

MCA- Middle cerebral artery

PCA - Posterior cerebral artery

ICA - Internal carotid artery

questions.text:
A man is rushed to the ER after losing control of his car and crashing into a tree. Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely cause for his presentation?

BP - 190/100 mmHg

Respiratory rate - 22/minute

GCS - 9/15

Temperature - 106.8 °F

Head and neck examination - Minor abrasions over the face

CNS - Quadriparesis. Pupils are 2 mm and unreactive.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pontine haemorrhage. Clinical features of pontine haemorrhage are:

  • Deep coma
  • Quadriparesis and multiple cranial nerve dysfunction
  • Decerebrate rigidity
  • Pin-point pupils
  • Hyperpnea, hyperpyrexia, severe hypertension, and hyperhidrosis

Option A: The presence of hyperpyrexia and pin-point pupils rule out the possibility of spinal cord trauma.

Option B: Morphine poisoning is a differential diagnosis for pin-point pupils. But it leads to slower respiratory rate, not tachypnea.

Option D: In ponto-medullary laceration, medullary involvement would cause respiratory depression, leading to apnea. But here tachypnea is noted.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and left-sided limb weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and her CT appears normal. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent stroke following TIA.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms.

The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using the ABCD2 score. 

Other options: 

Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke usually take time to appear on NCCT.

Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
Thrombolysis is contraindicated in which of the following patients with ischaemic stroke?

1. A patient brought to the ER within half an hour of onset of symptoms

2. A 57-year-old man brought to the ER within 3 hours of onset of symptoms and having platelet count of 180,000 / µL

3. A patient with a sustained BP of 190/120 mm of Hg

4. A patient with a history of gastrointestinal bleeding about a month ago

5. A patient who has recent history of myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
A sustained blood pressure > 185/110 mmHg and recent myocardial infarction are contraindications for initiating thrombolysis in ischemic stroke.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A patient with acute ischemic stroke requires IV thrombolysis. His symptoms had begun at 6:30 PM and he was brought to the hospital by 7:00 PM. For this treatment to be beneficial for the patient, it should be administered within what time?
questions.solution:
IV thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke has been proven to be beneficial up to 4.5 hours after the onset of symptoms according to European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study (ECASS) III.

According to MoHFW (India), thrombolysis is to be carried out within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.

IV tPA should be administered to all eligible acute stroke patients within 3 hours of last known normal and to a more selective group of eligible acute stroke patients (based on ECASS III exclusion criteria) within 4.5 hours of last known normal.

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated?
questions.solution:
Neglect is a feature of stroke that need not be treated. Although neglect indicates a poor prognosis, most patients recover without any treatment in 1-6 months.

Dysphagia(Option A) poses a high risk of aspiration and hence can't be left untreated. Spasticity(Option B) can be treated with baclofen, tizanidine. Untreated, it creates a psychosocial impact on the patient. Fever(Option C) is deleterious in stroke patients and must be treated.

Neglect can arise from injury to cortical-limbic-reticular network, that directs attention and integrates the localization and identification of a stimulus. Neglect is  associated with poor scores and slower recovery, but severe neglect is rare beyond 6 months. Recovery is rapid in the first 2 weeks, regardless of the side of stroke. By 3 months, patients might have some residual visual neglect. The choice of an intervention depends on the mechanism of neglect, the patient can be treated for an underaroused right hemisphere which has difficulty processing sensory inputs. 

Neurogenic dysphagia is an important cause of pulmonary infection in any patient with stroke, motor neuron disease, even transient dysphagia can lead to malnutrition, dehydration, aspiration pneumonia, and airway obstruction with asphyxia, it increases the risk of death and institutionalization. Early placement of  nasogastric tube to feed patients after stroke has improved nutrition and reduced deaths.

Spasticity is seen in less than 20% of stroke patients. Patients with bilateral weakness from hypoxic injury are likely to have signs of spasticity. Exaggerated cutaneous and autonomic reflexes and involuntary spasms are disabling problems associated with spasticity. Physical modalities like slow stretching movements and daily passive exercises will reduce symptoms of spasticity and risk of contractures. Baclofen, tizanidine, and clonidine are used in reducing clonus and extensor spasms.

questions.text: A woman on oral contraceptive pills presents with a headache for 2 days and paraparesis. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The presence of headache and paraparesis in this patient with a history of oral contraceptive use is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous thrombosis is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states such as:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections.

It presents with:

  • Headache (most common)
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial Hypertension
  • Focal neurological Deficits
  • Altered Mental status

MR venography is used for diagnosis.

The below image shows the empty delta sign seen on CECT or MRI with contrast in patients with sagittal sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a patient diagnosed with sagittal sinus thrombosis?
questions.solution:
IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia. 

Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.

If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus. 

Treatment of CVT:

  • Acute treatment - IV Heparin or LMWH
  • Maintenance therapy:
    • Warfarin for at least 3 months
    • In pregnant women with a history of CVT - anticoagulation with LMWH throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking also. Angiography shows a puff of smoke appearance. Which of the following statements regarding this disease is false?

choices.text: It is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries
Dawson’s fingers are the characteristic imaging finding

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Moyamoya disease and Dawson's fingers is not a finding in this condition. 

Dawson fingers are a radiographic feature typically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS)

The picture below demonstrates Dawson fingers.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries. It has a bimodal age distribution and is seen in the first and fourth decades:

  • Childhood moyamoya is characterized by ischemic manifestations
  • Adult moyamoya is characterized by hemorrhagic manifestations

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment is by surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery. This may prevent stroke and haemorrhage.

The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease.

Note: As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
Age > 60 years is not a component of the CHADS2-VASc score. Age > 75years and age group 65-75 yrs are the two age criteria considered in the score.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Anticoagulation therapy is given for all the patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

or aortic plaque)
